author: Morgan Eichensehr
title: Weinberg Foundation gifts $5M toward new Ronald McDonald House
text: Weinberg Foundation gifts $5M toward new Ronald McDonald House Feb 23, 2017, 1:00pm EST Industries & Tags Morgan Eichensehr Reporter Baltimore Business Journal Share The latest rendering of the new Ronald McDonald House in East Baltimore. Ronald McDonald House Charities of Baltimore Ronald McDonald House Charities Baltimore has received a $5 million grant from the Harry and Jeanette Weinberg Foundation , part of an ongoing fundraising effort toward a new project in East Baltimore. The gift will help fund the planned 60,000-square-foot Ronald McDonald House on city-owned land off East Baltimore Street in the Jonestown neighborhood. The nonprofit has raised $27.5 million toward a $30 million goal. The latest rendering of the new Ronald McDonald House in East Baltimore. Ronald McDonald House Charities of Baltimore The organization plans to break ground on the project this spring. Construction is expected to take 18-24 months. The new House, in the works for several years , is expected to help meet the growing need from families in Baltimore looking for a place to stay while their children receive treatment in area hospitals. Demand has increased at the current 22,000-square-foot House on Lexington Street, and about 30 to 35 families are placed on a waiting list nightly. The House has 37 rooms. The new five-story project at 1 Aisquith St. — near the McKim Community Center — could house about 55 additional families per night, according to the organization. “The magnitude of the Weinberg Foundation gift is overwhelming and transformative in every way...We can now bring this long dream to reality,” Sandra Pagnotti , CEO of the Ronald McDonald House Charities Baltimore, said in a statement. The new pew project will include an outdoor rooftop space and a two-story underground garage. The fundraising campaign has been led by Bill Paterakis, the CEO of Northeast Foods, and Chuck Langmead , a retired McCormick & Co. executive. Donors include the Paterakis/Tsakalos Family, the Johns Hopkins Hospital Children’s Center, Kennedy Krieger Institute , University of Maryland Medical Center, McDonald’s Owner Operators of Greater Baltimore and the Eastern Shore, Dresher Foundation, Edward St. John , France-Merrick Foundation, Northeast Foods, the Kenneth Battye Foundation, McCormick & Co., Bob Pascal , Peter Grimm , and The Kahlert Foundation. Construction and building partners include Beatty, Harvey and Coco Architects; Morris and Ritchie Associates; Whiting-Turner Contracting Co., Kirk Designs and Harbor East Management. Morgan is a reporter for the Baltimore Business Journal. She covers technology, education and health care. Industries
